rev.diff:
Line 57: Line 57:
An estimated 100,000 people marched through [[Athens]],<ref name="ABC protest" /><ref name=burns /> with some estimates stretching to 500,000.<ref name="turnout may 5 rallies"/> As protests gained momentum, a large group tried to storm the parliament building in [[Syntagma Square]] in Athens, where they scuffled with police, causing some of the [[Evzones]] (ceremonial guards) to flee from the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]].<ref name=burns /> The protesters accused members of parliament of being "thieves".<ref name="BBC protest" /> Riot police were able to push the crowds back with [[tear gas]], [[Hand grenade#Stun|flash bombs]] and [[smoke bombs]].<ref name="ABC protest" /> Nearby buildings, including a finance ministry building, were set on fire.<ref name="BBC protest" /> Prime Minister George Papandreou responded "Nobody has the right to violence ... Violence breeds violence."<ref name="BBC protest" />
An estimated 100,000 people marched through [[Athens]],<ref name="ABC protest" /><ref name=burns /> with some estimates stretching to 500,000.<ref name="turnout may 5 rallies"/> As protests gained momentum, a large group tried to storm the parliament building in [[Syntagma Square]] in Athens, where they scuffled with police, causing some of the [[Evzones]] (ceremonial guards) to flee from the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]].<ref name=burns /> The protesters accused members of parliament of being "thieves".<ref name="BBC protest" /> Riot police were able to push the crowds back with [[tear gas]], [[Hand grenade#Stun|flash bombs]] and [[smoke bombs]].<ref name="ABC protest" /> Nearby buildings, including a finance ministry building, were set on fire.<ref name="BBC protest" /> Prime Minister George Papandreou responded "Nobody has the right to violence ... Violence breeds violence."<ref name="BBC protest" />
â
[[image:Outside MARFIN bank.png|left|thumb|People paying their respects to the people who died on May 5.]]
+
[[image:Outside MARFIN bank.png|thumb|People paying their respects to the people who died on May 5.]]
At about 13:50 a small group of unknown persons threw [[Molotov cocktails]] at a [[Marfin Investment Group|Marfin Bank]] branch on [[Stadiou Street]], while others chanted [[anti-capitalist]] slogans.<ref name="BBC protest"/><ref name="ABC protest"/><ref name="Kathimerini protest"/> Most of the bank's employees managed to escape the burning building, but two employees who jumped from the second-story balcony were injured and two women and a man were found dead after the fire was extinguished.<ref name="Kerdos protest"/> The victims died of [[asphyxiation]] from toxic fumes when they were unable to escape from a roof exit blocked by debris. They had gone to work despite the general strike over fears of losing their jobs.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/may/09/greece-debt-crisis-euro-imf | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=The Greek spirit of resistance turns its guns on the IMF | first=Helena | last=Smith | date=2010-05-09}}</ref> They have been identified as Paraskevi Zoulia, 35, Angeliki Papathanasopoulou, 32 (who was four months pregnant) and Epaminondas Tsakalis, 36.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/in-athens-the-day-was-calm-then-came-night-1965609.html |title=In Athens the day was calm. Then came night |publisher=[[The Independent]] |date=2010-05-07 |accessdate=2010-05-07 | location=London | first1=John | last1=Lichfield | first2=Menelaos | last2=Tzafalias}}</ref> Papandreou called the incident a "murderous act".<ref name="BBC protest" /> [[Michalis Chrysohoidis]], the [[Minister for the Protection of the Citizen]], declared that "today is a black day for democracyÂ ... undemocratic forces have [latched on to] a peaceful demonstration of workers and now petrol bombs have killed three of our citizens and put an immediate danger to the lives of others."<ref name="Kerdos protest"/> He also stated that "the killers will be caught and punished accordingly". Police started a widespread search, with the help of closed-circuit television footage in order to detect and arrest the suspects. It was reported that fire crews had difficulty reaching the scene because of demonstrations moving through the area.<ref name="Kathimerini protest"/><ref name="pbs newshour interview"/> The police blamed "hooded youth" for the incident,<ref name="ABC protest" /> while protesters blamed police for starting the cycle of violence, police brutality for the escalation of conflict.<ref name="BBC protest" /> In response to the incident, the [[Greek Federation of Bank Employees' Unions]] blamed bank management for inadequate safety measures in the building and called for strike action.<ref name="bank employees strike"/>
At about 13:50 a small group of unknown persons threw [[Molotov cocktails]] at a [[Marfin Investment Group|Marfin Bank]] branch on [[Stadiou Street]], while others chanted [[anti-capitalist]] slogans.<ref name="BBC protest"/><ref name="ABC protest"/><ref name="Kathimerini protest"/> Most of the bank's employees managed to escape the burning building, but two employees who jumped from the second-story balcony were injured and two women and a man were found dead after the fire was extinguished.<ref name="Kerdos protest"/> The victims died of [[asphyxiation]] from toxic fumes when they were unable to escape from a roof exit blocked by debris. They had gone to work despite the general strike over fears of losing their jobs.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/may/09/greece-debt-crisis-euro-imf | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=The Greek spirit of resistance turns its guns on the IMF | first=Helena | last=Smith | date=2010-05-09}}</ref> They have been identified as Paraskevi Zoulia, 35, Angeliki Papathanasopoulou, 32 (who was four months pregnant) and Epaminondas Tsakalis, 36.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/in-athens-the-day-was-calm-then-came-night-1965609.html |title=In Athens the day was calm. Then came night |publisher=[[The Independent]] |date=2010-05-07 |accessdate=2010-05-07 | location=London | first1=John | last1=Lichfield | first2=Menelaos | last2=Tzafalias}}</ref> Papandreou called the incident a "murderous act".<ref name="BBC protest" /> [[Michalis Chrysohoidis]], the [[Minister for the Protection of the Citizen]], declared that "today is a black day for democracyÂ ... undemocratic forces have [latched on to] a peaceful demonstration of workers and now petrol bombs have killed three of our citizens and put an immediate danger to the lives of others."<ref name="Kerdos protest"/> He also stated that "the killers will be caught and punished accordingly". Police started a widespread search, with the help of closed-circuit television footage in order to detect and arrest the suspects. It was reported that fire crews had difficulty reaching the scene because of demonstrations moving through the area.<ref name="Kathimerini protest"/><ref name="pbs newshour interview"/> The police blamed "hooded youth" for the incident,<ref name="ABC protest" /> while protesters blamed police for starting the cycle of violence, police brutality for the escalation of conflict.<ref name="BBC protest" /> In response to the incident, the [[Greek Federation of Bank Employees' Unions]] blamed bank management for inadequate safety measures in the building and called for strike action.<ref name="bank employees strike"/>
